texts.definition: Numerical values used in games to determine winners.
markups: <style="Definition">Numerical values used in games to determine winners.</style>

Many games determine a winner for each game instance, or at least an ordering of how well players managed to reach the goals offered by the game (which can include having people tied in how well they succeeded). Games that do this through providing each player or team with a numerical value uses <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style>.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> use <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> to determine a winner. Some, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hare%20and%20Tortoise">Hare and Tortoise</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style>, end when a player has a high enough <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> while others, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carcassonne">Carcassonne</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Egizia">Egizia</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ticket%20to%20Ride">Ticket to Ride</link></style>, end due to specific requirements and <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> are then counted. Scenarios in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style> are typically not balanced between the two sides but through using scores for each game players can switch sides after a first game instance and compare their results of two game instances to get a balanced combined score.

<style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> are used to determine the winner in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> but not in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> (unless someone surrenders in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style>). However, in tournaments <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can be used based on winning individual game instances, and the rankings one can achieve through participating in organized games and tournaments can be seen as a type of meta <style="CurrentLink">Score</style>.

Several <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style> use <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> as ways of letting players of single-player games be able to compare themselves to other players and previous times they have played. Examples of such games include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bejeweled">Bejeweled</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Icy%20Tower">Icy Tower</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Staries">Staries</link></style>. "Deathmatch" version of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">FPS Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unreal%20Tournament%20series">Unreal Tournament series</link></style> have the number of kills one has made as <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> (killing oneself is typically counted as -1 kill). Other games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Candy%20Crush%20Saga">Candy Crush Saga</link></style>,  don't have global <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> but which level a player has reached can function as a form of <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> in them since it does show how far players have managed to progress.

Team vs. team play in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> give points to the infected team based on how far they managed to traverse a level. Since the teams have asymmetrical abilities and starting positions (like <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style>), the roles as reversed so both teams play as infected and the <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> they get are compared to determine winners.

The "ticket system" in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> can be seen as an inverse <style="CurrentLink">Score</style>. Each time starts with a certain amount and lose 1 ticket for each death in their team and not controlling enough flags result in tickets being removed at regular intervals. The amount of tickets the winning team has is through this basically a <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> like <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> in other games.

Designing a system for <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> in a game consists of deciding when players <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> are adjusted, how much they are adjusted by, and if there are certain <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> values which activate events, including ending the game. The last case is shows how <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can be part of defining <style="Link"><link="main-goals">Main Goals</link></style> and how <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can often create <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> (but see <style="Link"><link="king-hill">King of the Hill</link></style> for an alternative).

<style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> are typically a numeric value attached to individual players or <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>. In games where <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> are used to calculate victory, this combination of patterns create a type of <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> system. However, some other attributes can be viewed as <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> so games without explicit <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can have them implicitly. <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style> is one such example since they can represent how much effort and skill players have put into the gameplay. <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style> used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Golf">Golf</link></style> is another example since these can be seen as <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> in the <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Game</link></style> of being a good player in these games. In games where players progress in unlimited by lives over time and try to complete <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Candy%20Crush%20Saga">Candy Crush Saga</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Peggle">Peggle</link></style>, the scoring of which <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> one has completed in <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> serve a similar function to <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> in other <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>.

Generalizing, <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> are typically increased as <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> for succeeding with goals and decreased as <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> for failing to succeed with goals. <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> are two patterns which quite often are directly linked to providing increased <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style>. The actual update or finalization of <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> may be a <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> but dying may in itself result in <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> decreasing so the patterns can modify each other. <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style> can be used to both offer different starting <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> for players or to modify how they are given and removed, in both cases to create <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="revoke-rules">Revoke Rules</link></style> are a special case of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> that apply to players for failing to follow rules (typically in games with <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style>).

While increasing one's <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> can be a goal in itself, games sometimes provides <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> for reaching certain <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style>. A common examples is increasing the number of <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> one has when reaching certain <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style>; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pinball%20Dreams">Pinball Dreams</link></style> does this through providing a jackpot value common for all players that can provide <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can be seen as <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> in games where players have choices between trying to improve their possibilities to affect future gameplay, i.e. create <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style>, and getting points for their <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style>. Players of both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominion">Dominion</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style> need to make decisions of this nature as part of considering to do a <style="Link"><link="construction-scoring-phase-shift">Construction/Scoring Phase Shift</link></style>. When <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can intentionally be decreased by players as a way of performing others actions (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Murano">Murano</link></style> is an example of this), <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> become <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> (so they can be both <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> at the same time).

<style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can affect all types of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Winning%20Patterns">Winning Patterns</link></style>. For games with <style="Link"><link="winning-ending-gameplay">Winning by Ending Gameplay</link></style>, they can either be the cause of gameplay ending when a player reaches a certain <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> or be <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style> if several players can end gameplay at the same time. For <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> they are a form of  <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style> while they are typically the prime way of determining winners in games using <style="Link"><link="winner-gameplay-ends">Winner determined after Gameplay Ends</link></style> but may be complemented by <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style>. While <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> rather obviously give players ways of having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> against each other, they can work the same way in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> through the use of <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High Score Lists</link></style> to let players compete against themselves or others through comparing <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> between game instances (an example of using <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style>).

The possibilities of increasing <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can be set up so that they become <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> choices, typically that one takes higher risks of not getting any points (or a risk of getting negative points) for the chance of getting more points if one gets any points at all. The distribution of  individual ways of increasing (or decreasing) <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can be set up to follow <style="Link"><link="arithmetic-progression">Arithmetic</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Discontinuous%20Progression">Discontinuous Progression</link></style>. Motivations for which of these progression schemes as most suitable depend very much on the specifics of a game design but <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style> may be more suitable in cases where a design should have <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="time-limited-game-instances">Time Limited Game Instances</link></style> can be used to put implicit maximum limits to the <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> possible and let players compete on being as quick as possible in gathering points rather than as efficient as possible.

<style="Link"><link="end-state-scoring">End State Scoring</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="secret-scoring-mechanisms">Secret Scoring Mechanisms</link></style> are two general ways of modifying how <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> work in a game, both promoting <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can easily be tied to <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gambling">Gambling</link></style>, i.e. through requiring payment in money to play and offering payment back as <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>.

When tying events and <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style> to <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> it may be necessary to consider if <style="Link"><link="tied-results">Tied Results</link></style> are possible and should be allowed. <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style> is the solution to avoid having <style="Link"><link="tied-results">Tied Results</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> are often difficult to explain within a game's theme, so using it easily breaks <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> and often thereby also <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> are typically important information in games where they are used, and for this reason often part of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-statistics">Gameplay Statistics</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="score-tracks">Score Tracks</link></style> is a specific interface (or visualization) component dedicated for this.

<style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> are probably the most basic and one of the most used elements in <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>. They make games have the <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goal</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style> points which can also be seen as a <style="Link"><link="races">Race</link></style> to either first reach a certain <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> or have the highest <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> when gameplay ends. Through this they act as <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style> in the sense that they facilitate players in being able to end or win games. They make easy values to use as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style> which can result in <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> for those with low <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style>, and can easily act as <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style> in games built to use <style="Link"><link="back-back-game-sessions">Back-to-Back Game Sessions</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style> being an example of this). In games with phases, a focus on increasing one's <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> as much as possible it typically a characteristics of an <style="Link"><link="exploitation">Exploitation</link></style> phase.

If <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> can be used as <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, they are typically <style="Link"><link="non-localized-resources">Non-Localized Resources</link></style>. When publicly accessible, they simultaneously are a type of <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> which create <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>. This can give rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dynamic%20Alliances">Dynamic Alliances</link></style> working against a <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. While wanting to win over other players can be sufficient reason for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Multiplayer">Multiplayer</link></style> games to have <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> can promote <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> in trying to beat one's own <style="CurrentLink">Score</style> from previous game instances and this can be seen as a weak use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style> (a stronger such use of <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> is through the use of <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High Score Lists</link></style>).

<style="Link"><link="save-points">Save Points</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style> tend to not work well with <style="CurrentLink">Scores</style> since players can go back repeatedly in attempts to maximize their scores.
